content.webTitle: UK campaign to end violence against women must be bolder, says aid watchdog

fields.headline: UK campaign to end violence against women must be bolder, says aid watchdog
fields.bodyText: The UK’s campaign to end violence against women and girls in developing countries has put the issue “firmly on the international agenda” but needs to be far bigger and bolder if it is to have real impact, the independent aid watchdog has warned. In a report, the Independent Commission for Aid Impact (Icai) praises the Department for International Development (DfID) for demonstrating global leadership on the issue and helping to increase knowledge and evidence. Since 2012, DfID has almost doubled the number of programmes dedicated to tackling gender-based violence – from 64 to 127 – while spending has increased from £20m to £184m. Two years ago, the UK hosted the high-profile, international Girl Summit to focus attention on ending child marriage and female genital mutilation. The study, billed as a learning review, gives DfID a green rating – the highest – saying the department has shown “strong achievement across the board” and that UK aid is making a “significant positive contribution”. But it warns the department that its efforts will not deliver “transformative impact” until it scales up its projects, sets specific targets and indicators for its work, and collects the necessary data to help it assess whether its programmes yield value for money. Tina Fahm, Icai’s lead commissioner for the review, said that while there was much to commend, DfID should not underestimate the work needed to tackle what the report terms a “global epidemic” of violence against women and girls. “DfID should be praised for translating its ambitions and commitment into innovative and effective programmes with the potential to make a real difference to a daunting challenge,” she said. “This is a promising start, but it is only the beginning. The test now is for DfID to step up its work to tackle violence against women and girls, which remains small in scale when compared to the huge problem.” The review advises DfID to use its influence to catalyse action from other countries and also highlights concerns that women’s voices – especially those at grassroots level – are not being adequately heard. It suggests the department could do more to tackle violence by strengthening and funding local women’s rights organisations and networks, describing it as a “relatively neglected area in DfID’s programming”. Bethan Cansfield, acting head of policy for Womankind Worldwide, welcomed the report – particularly its findings on supporting grassroots organisations. “Evidence shows that investing in women’s rights organisations is the smart option: these organisations are providing innovative, locally relevant and, at times, at scale interventions to end violence against women and girls,” she said. But despite their well-documented contribution, added Cansfield, women’s rights organisations often struggle to carry out their work because of lack of funding. She added: “We hope DfID urgently and significantly increases funding for women’s rights organisations to ensure [their] important work continues.” Anne Quesney, women’s rights advocacy adviser at ActionAid, said: “The report demonstrates that when policy commitments are prioritised, progress happens. We are calling on the UK government to commit to boosting the proportion of aid going directly to women’s rights groups working on the frontline. ActionAid [recommends] at least £70m over the next three years to be taken from the existing aid budget.” A DfID spokesperson said: “This report is absolutely right to underline Britain’s leading role in the global effort to put a stop to violence against women and girls. “But there is more to do, which is why we continue to put their rights and wellbeing at the heart of our development programme, helping millions of women and girls around the world build a future free from suffering.”
